column1: LaPlace ( lə-PLAHSS) is a census-designated place (CDP) in St. John the Baptist Parish
column4: situated along the east bank of the Mississippi River
column5: in the New Orleans metropolitan area. The population was 32

column1: LaPlace is the southern terminus of Interstate 55
column4: where it terminates at the junction with US 61. LaPlace is located 25 miles (40 km) west of New Orleans.

column1: The Chitimacha lived in the region prior to the arrival of European colonists. The tribe’s lands once encompassed the entire Atchafalaya Basin
column4: southward to the Gulf of Mexico and eastward to the New Orleans area. The Chitimacha Tribe currently resides on a reservation in St. Mary Parish

column1: Present-day LaPlace was settled by German immigrants in the early 18th century during Louisiana's French colonial period
column2: as part of a larger settlement on the bank of the Mississippi called Karlstein. Karlstein was one of the four settlements collectively known as the "German Coast" (French: "La Côte des Allemands")
column3: having been populated by German-speaking immigrants since 1721. French and Acadians intermarried with the Germans
column4: and the area came to be known as Bonnet Carré (English: "square bonnet"). The name Bonnet Carré was inspired by the right-angle turn of the Mississippi river near the settlement and its resemblance to a square bonnet.

column1: Manual Andry built Woodland plantation in 1793
column2: and cultivated sugarcane. The crop was lucrative if brutal methods were used
column3: as had been common in Haiti (and had led to a successful slave rebellion there). In early January 1811
column4: slaves at Woodland Plantation and several nearby plantations attempted the German Coast Uprising. A group of 200-500 slaves armed with guns
column6: and cane knives set out from LaPlace to conquer New Orleans and gain freedom for themselves and others. Local white "militia" men crushed the rebellion within three days
column7: and nearly 100 slaves were either killed in battle
column9: or executed after summary trials by planter tribunals. Although more slaves may have participated in the Black Seminole rebellion in 1836 and the whole of the Second Seminole War
column10: this is now considered the largest slave rebellion.

column4: and patent medicine purveyor Basile Laplace arrived from New Orleans
column5: and established a large plantation in Bonnet Carré. In 1883 he allowed the New Orleans and Baton Rouge Railroad to cut through his land. The settlement's railroad depot was named after Laplace
column7: and eventually the town itself.In the 1920s
column8: Woodland Plantation was bought by the Montegut family
column9: but the most famous person born there may have been Kid Ory
column10: who was born in an outbuilding and later led a successful New Orleans jazz band.

column2: the levee on the east bank of the Mississippi flooded several times. In 1850
column3: a flood created the Bonnet Carré Crevasse
column4: a levee breach that was more than a mile wide. Several major floods were exacerbated by this crevasse near LaPlace and one resulted in severe flooding of New Orleans in 1871. The breach was closed in 1883.In 2012
column6: 000 houses were damaged by flooding in LaPlace during Hurricane Isaac.In February 2016 and again in March 2016
